accused.name: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
accused.residence: Nancy (quarters of porter at porte St Nicolas)

confession.seduction_context: Confessed to using invocations of evil spirits and curses from magical books to cause illness, but denied being a witch in the traditional sense. Admitted making people ill through 'parolles' (words) and imprecations so they would consult him and buy him drinks

witnesses.name: Jean Montaigne
witnesses.occupation: soldier in company of Comte de Palin

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard and his wife
Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard and his wife

harms_alleged.target: himself, his wife, and their children

testimony.quarrel_subject: Wife went elsewhere to obtain cheaper milk

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after eating meat from cow Bragard killed
died of 'la pourpeliere' after initial healing
2 months earlier after refusing to lend 4 écus

testimony.quarrel_subject: Bragard's wife angry at seeing other cows than hers on ramparts
testimony.threat_quote: diable, diable, quant je t'auray guery ton enfans tu diras que je suis ung sorcier et me feras brusler

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: as soon as child tried to eat dinner on ramparts

witnesses.name: Mre Jean Racaillon
witnesses.occupation: marchal de l'estat de Mgr de Vaudemont (farrier in service of Lord of Vaudemont)

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard or his wife and daughter

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: body became twisted, could not eat
pain in right foot moving up body during pregnancies

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard or his wife and daughter

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: year before Christmas (1592), felt smothered in prison
year earlier, swelling and inflammation of leg
4 months before testimony, after Mariotte left gilded silver as surety

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Investigation followed accusation by Mengeon femme Jacques Vosgien. Evidence taken by Comte de Palin's lieutenants in presence of prévôt of Nancy

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Interrogation by officers of company. Admitted treating people with touch and Latin Gospel texts. Denied most specific allegations but confirmed using paternoster backwards

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Interrogation before Change de Nancy. Detailed questioning about magical books and practices

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Continued interrogation about use of magical recipes, circles, invocations

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses. Bragard admitted much of what was alleged

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: PG de Lorraine (Rémy) asks that he, his wife and daughter be given question extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Tortured with thumbscrews and strappado with 100 pound weights on each foot. Confessed to causing illnesses through words and invocations

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approved death sentence with strangling and burning. Books to be burned in his presence

timeline.subject: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
timeline.details: Death by strangling and burning. Magical books and materials to be burned in special fire

methods: strappado with 100 pound weights on each foot

prior_accusations.context: Esprouvier (hawk keeper) of Nancy. Her accusation triggered the formal investigation

notable_quotes.speaker: Mariotte (Bragard's daughter)
notable_quotes.french: sy elle la guerissoit elle diroit comme les aultres qu'elle estoit sorciere
notable_quotes.english: if she healed her she would say like the others that she was a witch
notable_quotes.context: Refusing to help Pieron's wife who was dying

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
notable_quotes.french: diable, diable, quant je t'auray guery ton enfans tu diras que je suis ung sorcier et me feras brusler
notable_quotes.english: devil, devil, when I have healed your child you will say I am a witch and have me burned
notable_quotes.context: To Guillemart while treating his daughter

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
notable_quotes.french: vela qui vaut pire qu'un diable elle ne s'en taira jamais, et scais bien qu'elle me fera brusler quelques jours, et que c'estoit tout un et ne s'en soucir point qu'il ne pouvoit faillir de l'estre au pis allé
notable_quotes.english: there is one who is worse than a devil, she will never keep quiet, and I know well she will have me burned some day, and it's all the same and he doesn't care because he cannot fail to be at worst
notable_quotes.context: Pointing to Guillemart's wife, expressing fatalism about being executed

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Racaillon (witness 5)
notable_quotes.french: qu'ils se meslent tous de sortileges que plusieurs de ses voisins estoient malades et allons aupres de luy, ont esté guery
notable_quotes.english: they all dabble in sorcery and several of his neighbors were sick and went to him and were healed
notable_quotes.context: General testimony about Bragard family's reputation

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard
notable_quotes.french: qu'il voyoit bien qu'il s'en alloit mourir, mais qu'il suplioit tres humblement Monseigneur luy vouloir pardonner les fautes qu'en ce que dessus il auroit commises ne l'ayant jamais faict qu'a bonne intention
notable_quotes.english: that he saw well he was going to die, but begged most humbly that the Lord would pardon him the faults he had committed in the above, having never done it except with good intention
notable_quotes.context: End of first interrogation on June 28, 1593

relationships.evidence_text: His wife Cunatte and daughter Mariotte were also suspected
fellow soldiers in company of Comte de Palin
Bragard and his family had often been in his house, because they were neighbours
Mengeon femme Jacques Vosgien, esprouvier de Nancy
enquiries in shop of the esprouvier, their neighbour

economic_context.details: Economic tensions around milk sales (cheaper milk elsewhere), lending money (refused to lend Cunatte 4 écus), and payment for healings. Bragard expected to be bought drinks/food as payment for healing services. Comte de Salm confiscated property but later returned it to wife and daughter

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill with abscesses in various parts of body, died after 9 months. Small piece of rope found on child's stomach day before death
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard and his wife

harms_catalog.harm_description: Strange gust of wind, child cried out, mouth open and tongue protruding, died 2 days later
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard and his wife
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 4 years before testimony (while living at porte St Nicolas)

harms_catalog.victim_name: Jean Montaigne, his wife, and children
harms_catalog.harm_description: Constantly ill for last 4 years while living in quarters at porte St Nicolas
Great pain in one breast after eating cherries left by Mariotte, spent night crying in great pain
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Wife went elsewhere to obtain cheaper milk

harms_catalog.harm_description: Died 'eticq' (consumptive/wasting disease) after testifying against Bragard family
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: shortly after another woman revealed what she had said

harms_catalog.victim_name: Child being nursed by Pieron's wife
harms_catalog.harm_description: Died shortly after the nursing woman died
Very ill 2.5 years earlier, worried about moving house
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft, healed after dining with them

harms_catalog.harm_description: Ill for 2 weeks after eating meat from cow Bragard killed
Unable to keep food down, had 'la fourchette de coeur avallée'
Died of 'la pourpeliere' after initial healing by Bragard
Fell ill again after wife refused to lend Cunotte 4 écus
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft, healed when money lent to buy wheat

harms_catalog.harm_description: Body became all twisted, could not eat, had side where stomach should be and vice versa. Left with occasional pain in side after healing
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Anger at seeing other cows than hers on ramparts
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: as soon as child tried to take first mouthful of dinner

harms_catalog.harm_description: Suddenly became paralysed and twisted, seemed about to die. Finally healed but not completely, likely to suffer for whole life
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard or his wife and daughter

harms_catalog.harm_description: Pain that started in right foot and moved up, only ceasing after delivery. Experienced 3 times during pregnancies. Bragard said it was witchcraft
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Nicolas Noel dit le Bragard (according to him)

harms_catalog.harm_description: Felt something trying to smother him in prison, became very ill and thought likely to die
Great swelling and inflammation of her leg
Fluxion, ill for 10 weeks. Apothecary said no remedy, must let it take its course
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Mariotte left gilded silver as surety for wine

material_culture.context: Mariotte left cherries with Pieron's wife, who became ill after eating them
Bragard's wife sold expensive milk. Children ate well when bought from her, not when bought elsewhere. Source of economic tension
Cunotte brought meat from cow Bragard had killed to Pieron. He became ill after eating it
Witnesses obliged to drink wine with Bragard during healing treatments. Mariotte bought wine from innkeeper
Used in healing ointments (4 eggs, vinegar, lard, nine oils). Also cooked on red-hot pan for treatments
Used in ointment for healing (eggs, vinegar, lard, oils)
Used in healing ointment
Used in healing ointment from Bragard's house
Specific ingredient Bragard instructed wife to add to ointments

material_culture.object: holy water from Easter and Whitsun
material_culture.context: Mariotte brought holy water to drink for 9 days as part of healing treatment
Small piece of rope found on dying child's stomach. Also Bragard allegedly used rope to tie up tree during healing ritual
Bragard placed sick children on pillows during healing
Mengeon refused to lend this amount to Cunotte; husband fell ill until she lent money
Mariotte left as surety for wine. Innkeeper became ill week later
Multiple books containing recipes for invocations, finding lost objects, gaining love, etc. Some in Latin, some in French. Written in Bragard's hand
Found with Bragard's magical materials. Depicted woman naked to waist on one side, number 7 and name Venus on other. Wrapped in virgin parchment
Similar to lead medal, possibly pawned by wife
Given to Bragard with medals, possibly pawned by wife
From his late mother's funeral, kept for memory
To be used for magical recipe involving seduction
Used to cure toothache by pricking point between two lines where word 'Macabeus' was written
Used to draw magical circle for invoking sibyl
Told Jean Gillet to buy, beat well, and apply to wife's swollen leg
Used in herbal baths and soups for healing. Fetched from Bragard's house
Burned as fumigations in healing treatments
Cunotte needed money to buy wheat at mill
Bragard described using these in healing (Delcambre p. 111)
Used for divination to find lost objects ('torner la clef')

spatial_references.context: Main location of trial, where Bragard lived and worked as soldier
Quarters of porter where Bragard and family lived for last 4 years. Montaigne's family constantly ill there
Where Guillemart's daughter was guarding cows and became bewitched. Bragard's daughters no longer dared go there. Montaigne's child fell from ramparts
Where Jean Marchal was porter, from whom Bragard first learned magic
Bragard's birthplace, where he was cobbler before coming to Nancy
Where Bragard went 20 years earlier to discover thieves who had stolen 120 francs from Nicolas Bourbon
Where Bragard tried to find treasure using magical recipe on St. John's day
Bragard accused Colas's wife of visiting priests there; she denied it
Inn kept by Marguerite Valliere where Mariotte bought wine
Where late Pierrot worked as guard, source of charms against wolves
Origin of Bigouy who gave Bragard magical medals

historical_context.military_details: Nicolas Noel was soldier in company of Comte de Palin for 30 years. Multiple witnesses were soldiers. Company structure important for trial jurisdiction. Comte de Salm later returned property to wife and daughter and expelled them from duchy
economic_hardship_indicators: Need to borrow money to buy wheat
Economic pressure visible in healing as transaction requiring payment in drinks/food
religious_calendar_references: St. John's day (for magical treasure hunting)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Mgr le comte had forbidden Bragard more than 10 years earlier to practice divinations and find lost property
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Prohibition ignored; Bragard continued with permission of company officers

prior_legal_disputes.description: Captain d'Ailly later called Bragard to count's house to use key-turning divination to find stolen money
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Bragard thought this gave him permission to continue

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean Guillemart imprisoned for killing a gentleman in quarrel. Bragard visited him in prison
Guillemart's wife imprisoned for calling Bragard's wife witch
Sr de la Ferté deprived Bragard of company of soldiers. Rumor he made threats

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Wife Cunatte and daughter Mariotte were arrested with him but not executed

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved death sentence and added that books and magical materials should be burned in his presence in a special fire

hearsay_chains.content: Conversation with Bragard about possible arrest and execution
Bragard had healed Guillemart's child and taught children to say paternoster backwards
Revealed what Pieron's wife had said as witness, after which she became ill and died

emotional_state_notes: Expressed fatalism about being executed ('I know well she will have me burned some day')
Before torture, asked to be spared, promised to tell truth
Finally resigned, asked for pardon, claimed good intentions
Said he saw well he was going to die

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said Jean Guillemart 'hante souvent les femmes ne se contantant de la sienne' (frequents women often, not content with his own)
Said Guillemart's wife had been imprisoned for calling his wife witch
Said he heard Colas's wife had been to visit priests at Pont-à-Mousson (she denied indignantly)

third_parties.name: Mengeon femme Jacques Vosgien
third_parties.context: Esprouvier (hawk keeper) of Nancy who made initial accusation of witchcraft that triggered investigation

third_parties.name: Jacques Vosgien
third_parties.context: Had head twisted backwards, healed by Bragard. Bragard healed him 2 or 3 times. His wife made the accusation

third_parties.name: Guillemart (child of witness 1)
third_parties.context: Bragard healed his child, then allegedly taught his other children to say paternoster backwards

third_parties.name: Mengin Pouchardin
third_parties.context: Another soldier who talked with Bragard about possible arrest

third_parties.name: Cunatte
third_parties.context: Arrested with husband and daughter, suspected of witchcraft. Present during imprecations. Later released and expelled from duchy

third_parties.name: Mariotte
third_parties.context: Arrested with parents, suspected of witchcraft. Brought holy water for healings, sold milk, left bewitched cherries and gilded silver. Later released and expelled

third_parties.name: Jean Marchal
third_parties.context: Late porter at porte de la Craffe, had book of magical recipes that first interested Bragard in magic

third_parties.name: Jacques Louys
third_parties.context: Dead soldier who showed Bragard book of recipes but wouldn't lend it

third_parties.name: Guillaume Collignon
third_parties.context: Dead soldier who gave Bragard book with magical recipes

third_parties.name: Sr de Precicourt Haulton
third_parties.context: Bought most of Bragard's transcribed magical books

third_parties.name: Eldest son of late sieur Baruet
third_parties.context: Showed Bragard book titled 'De occulta philosophia', believed to be fourth book of Agrippa

third_parties.name: Claudine des Prunes
third_parties.context: Woman Bragard tried to seduce using magical invocations to Astorothe

third_parties.name: Bigouy de Bar
third_parties.context: Former servant of late sire Jean de Lincourt, gave Bragard lead and silver medals and silver ring

third_parties.name: Daniel
third_parties.context: Servant to Sr Claudin Jenin, participated in circle-making and spirit invocations with Bragard and his son 16 years earlier

third_parties.name: Bragard's son
third_parties.context: Participated in magical circle and invocations with father and Daniel 16 years earlier

third_parties.name: Nicolas Bourbon
third_parties.context: Had 120 francs stolen; Bragard went to Tremblaine to discover thieves using magic 20 years earlier

third_parties.name: Pierrot (late guard at barrier)
third_parties.context: Dead guard on way to St Jean, source of charms against wolves and for curing cow diseases

third_parties.name: Sr de la Ferté
third_parties.context: Deprived Bragard of company of soldiers, sent papers about magical recipes to court

third_parties.name: Comte de Palin
third_parties.context: Commander of military company where Bragard served

third_parties.name: Late captain d'Ailly
third_parties.context: Called Bragard to count's house to use divination to find stolen money, which Bragard interpreted as permission

third_parties.name: Jacques Collignon
third_parties.context: Maire of Petincourt who taught Bragard 48 years earlier how to manipulate twisted limbs

third_parties.name: Penthecoste femme Jean Poinselet
third_parties.context: Woman Bragard cured of broken spine 40 years earlier

third_parties.name: Rousel (apothecary)
third_parties.context: Diagnosed innkeeper's illness as 'fluxion' with no remedy

third_parties.name: Alix (Guillemart's daughter)
third_parties.context: One of daughters Bragard allegedly tried to teach paternoster backwards

third_parties.name: Marguerite (Guillemart's daughter)
third_parties.context: One of daughters Bragard allegedly tried to teach paternoster backwards

third_parties.name: Two surgeons
third_parties.context: Present during torture session on July 13, 1593

extraction_metadata.notes: Exceptionally detailed trial record. This is an unusual case - Bragard was a folk healer/cunning man who practiced ritual magic from books (grimoires), rather than a traditional witch. He confessed under torture to causing illnesses through invocations of evil spirits and curses, but maintained he did it to generate healing business, not from a pact with the devil. His wife and daughter were arrested but released and banished. The case reveals extensive magical practice including divination, treasure hunting, love magic, and spirit invocation. Notable for the quantity of material culture evidence (books, medals, ritual objects) and the complexity of his healing practices. PG was Nicolas Rémy, famous witch-trial judge and author of Daemonolatreiae.
